from sklearn.model_selection import KFold
from sklearn import model_selection, preprocessing, metrics

import os
print(os.listdir("../input"))
from sklearn import preprocessing
import xgboost as xgb
import gc


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

source.1f59a24d:
train, test = model_selection.train_test_split(train_test, test_size=0.33, random_state=42, shuffle=True)
del train_test
gc.collect()
source.203bdc5f:
train_y = train['target'].values
test_y = test['target'].values
del train['target'], test['target']
gc.collect()
source.99c5e125:
train = lgb.Dataset(train, label=train_y)
test = lgb.Dataset(test, label=test_y)
source.d0b278fe:
num_round = 500
clf = lgb.train(param, train, num_round, valid_sets = [train, test], verbose_eval=50, early_stopping_rounds = 50)
source.cbb75634:
feature_imp = pd.DataFrame(sorted(zip(clf.feature_importance(),FEAT_COLS)), columns=['Value','Feature'])

plt.figure(figsize=(20, 10))
sns.barplot(x="Value", y="Feature", data=feature_imp.sort_values(by="Value", ascending=False).head(20))
plt.title('LightGBM Features')
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
plt.savefig('lgbm_importances-01.png')

source.4c9f5714: So with AUC of about 0.74, there seems to be a farily significant difference in distribution of features that we have used between the train and test sets. So let's take a look at what features are most responsible for this difference:
